title: Liandry's Torment has an identity crisis
body:
Is it a tank buster? % health damage suggests so. But the damage is underwhelming at best.

Is it a squishy squasher? 15 magic pen suggests so. However, the mpen is almost useless vs tanks. Consider this - 15 magic pen increases your damage to targets based on their mr as follows:

Target w/ 15 mr: 15% damage increase
Target w/ 50 mr: 11.1% damage increase
Target w/ 100 mr: 8.1% damage increase
Target w/ 200 mr: 5.2% damage increase
Target w/ 300 mr: 3.9% damage increase

This means that with 15 mpen you do the above percentages MORE damage to the target than you did without the 15 mpen. Since you aren't doing much damage vs high mr targets to begin with, the percent increase means even less. Below you see the absolute percent damage increase (target's percent damage reduction WITH your 15 mpen **minus** target's percent damage reduction WITHOUT your 15 mpen).

Target w/ 15 mr: 13% 
Target w/ 50 mr: 7.4% 
Target w/ 100 mr: 4% 
Target w/ 200 mr: 1.7%
Target w/ 300 mr: 1%


Is it a tank item? The 300 hp suggests so. But it feels so out of place. Especially since there are many other items you can get hp from.

So in what situation should you buy liandry's? It feels that in every situation you are losing out on efficiency with this item.

replies.body:
It's a great damage item for DoT champions.
The health gives survivability so they can keep casting throughout a fight without getting bursted down as easily.
Magic penetration increases its potentness against squishies.
% HP increases its effectiveness against tanky champs.

It's just a well-rounded damage item for mages who generally lack burst.
The %HP scales with the enemy's stat, rather than AP, so that makes it good for supports who don't buy AP. Zyra, Brand, Malzahar come to mind.
As a support main, that last sentence sickens me.

It's a great item for Rylai's users*

Liandries is a great item for DoT mages because they can continuously apply the burn. Ryalis is a great item for DoT mages because they can continuously apply the slow. 

Liandries isnt great because of the Rylais. There are champions that can use Rylais very effectively that dont have a DoT "style", so I wouldnt suggest getting Liandries on though a Ryalis (Kennan/Eve/Akali/Ahri/Kayle/Cho). They benefit from Ryalis to keep enemies within their "zone of damger", but dont have the slow spells to really benefit from Liandries.
I've actually messed around with Liandry's on Cho'Gath before just because his AA's will continually reapply it in an AoE.
Have tried this and it's surprisingly effective.

Liandry's might have synergy with champs who have DoT, but those same champs have a bigger synergy with _both_ Rylai's and Liandry's due to their innate DoT applying Rylai's, thus apply Liandry's extra passive damage.

Which I'm not saying is wrong - but the common factor of both Liandries and Rylais optimal effectiveness is the DoT mages. Liandries isnt a great item for Ryali's users, its a great item for DoT champions. 

Which is why I took the time to point out champions who are Rylais users who arent DoT mages, and therefore arent often seen with the Liandries/Ryalis combo.

It's also great for AP bruisers.

It provides everything they need:
Survivability
Pen for squishies
% damage against tanky opponents
A good amount of AP

And it synergies well with Rylais.

Liandry's Torment does not exist to be bought, it is intended to be a deterrent.

The item's niche is that it is extremely punishing against tanks who do not build MR (when Liandry's was first created it was common to rush Warmog's Armor). Your analysis is spot on in that it cannot do much to a squishy or a tank who itemizes against it, but try running the numbers of a 4000 health target with just 52 MR, you'll see the DPS.

Liandry's has been around long enough that it has accomplished its job. Tanks do not try and survive burst merely by stacking health and armor anymore. But you can't remove Liandry's because without the deterrent the desired change will just revert.

Its sustained magic damage with some health attached to it. Clearly meant for winning drawn out battles. Think of it as a more offensive sunfire cape.

If you want to bust tanks build a void staff

That's what he's saying. Why does an item that offers % max health damage also give flat mpen, and then dilute both stats with health? A better option for bursting squishies is to build pure AP, while a better option for bruising tanks is to take Void Staff. It's an awkward middleground item that gives you a little bit of this this and that, but doesn't solidify the identity of the champions that use it or appeal to anyone in particular except as synergy with Rylai's for the 3 champions that happen to build that.

Drawn-out battles are meant to be won by adc's and bruisers, not by AP casters, who are generally supposed to burst unprotected targets from a distance. It just so happens that the 3 AP casters who build Rylai's/Liandry's are the three who are meta as supports (those champs being Zyra, Brand, and Malzahar) meaning your team will still have an actual mage to burst down targets or an assassin to do the same job.

> If you want to bust tanks build a void staff

Actually if you want to bust tanks pick a different mage.

Some mages (Malzahar, Brand, Cassi, Annie to an extent) are good at hurting tanks, while others (Lux, Syndra, Veigar) just aren't.  If you aren't playing a good tank-busting mage, then you're out of luck against a big tank pile, unfortunately - there just really aren't any good tank busting mage items.

It's why full AD comps can sometimes work but full AP comps don't really.

edit: as a point of clarification - it's generally low cooldown, single target abilities that are pretty good against tanks, or massive amounts of % health damage.  The reason why mages are so varied is that not every mage possesses an ability like that.  ADCs, on the other hand, are not so varied; every single marksman in the game has a low cooldown, high DPS single target ability (auto attacks).
how dare you exclude {{champion:161}} our true damage savior.

Eh, he's actually pretty okay at beating tanks, he does do a ton of true damage, and can kite them pretty well.

But he's even better at deleting squishies.

(seriously, at full build you can just press R on an ADC and they die)

> while others (Lux, Syndra, Veigar) just aren't

I dunno man, Veigar is generally one of those burst mages who can burst so obscenely hard he'll wind up deleting tanks as well, if only because they're the only ones who're still around after a Q-W combo.

Technically you're not wrong, Veigar can eventually mass enough AP to start to blow through tanks too.  It takes a long time, though, and for most of the game he's pretty weak against them - it's kind of a waste to ult a tank too, unless it's the fed person on their team (in which case you really do need to remove them faster).

As you said, they are the only ones left standing, but even with high CDR he has fairly long cooldowns to actually finish the job.

> [{quoted}](name=Hexs Fortune,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=EKrfbpKo,comment-id=0005,timestamp=2017-02-04T03:02:47.174+0000)

> If you want to bust tanks build a void staff

Funny you mention that. The 35% magic pen actually helps more with medium mr targets. The absolute percent damage increase, as defined in my original post, peaks (at ~10.7%) when the target has about 120 mr, and then goes down from there. Even though the relative damage increase (percent damage increase compared to the damage you were doing before) continues to increase as target mr increases, the actual damage value that is increased by the m pen gets lower, since the higher mr target takes less damage in the first place.

Though to accurately gauge whether Void Staff is doing its job or not, you need to compare whether buying raw AP would be more efficient at any given point, which is... actually rather complicated, and differs greatly on a champion-to-champion basis. It is funny, though, how much people overestimate pen against high resist targets, just because of the large numbers it changes.

You're thinking about this all wrong. Liandries is an item for AP champs with low AP ratios. Both the magic pen and the % burn are there to supplement mages with high base damages but low AP ratios; think Zyra, Brand, etc. It's the same reason it used to be a must buy on Vel'koz before his rework.

Flat magic pen combined with %HP damage punishes low resist, high HP targets.

This isn't difficult to figure out.

{{item:3151}} was originally meant to counter health-only tanks few seasons ago. If this item is gone, then we'd potentially start seeing HP-stacking zero resistance {{champion:36}} {{champion:154}} {{champion:113}} tank assassins in this "ADC in 2017 LUL" meta

You know who likes that item?

{{champion:50}} THIS CRAZY BIRD MAN RIGHT HERE.

It gives him HP, and allows him to fight better against the tanks who may be able to draw him into a prolonged fight that can drain his mana. Rylai's + Liandry's makes him extremely sticky during his ult, spread out a constant %HP AoE slow, and gives him health and AP.

It may not be -core- itemization, but it is certainly useful against tankier compositions.
if they want it to be anti-tank, it should do %missing health instead of %current health and have that Giant Slayer passive but for magic damage  tbh

%missing health is just %max health that only works well against targets who are half health or less. It's hardly any different, it's just weaker, and would make Liandry's even worse at its supposed job of poking down high health tanks.

Weaker? Right now it's only good on champs who throw out one small ability and run away. It would be better with %missing health, because enemies get lower health *after* a champ uses all his abilities on them.
Well I mean it's a mask tho

Ok, I see what you're trying to argue now.

Let me ask you something. What has a bigger effect on the game:

1) Killing an opponent in 1 hit instead of 2, or
2) Killing an opponent in 39 hits instead of 40?

You are assuming that each reduced hit required has an equal value. In case 1 you just reduced the time to kill the target in half. You doubled your damage!! In case 2 you hardly reduced your time to kill the target at all. You hardly increased your damage. Ironically, YOU are the one with the misleading argument. I really can't make it easier for you to understand. You are just very confused.

Again, I'm not saying that flat pen is what you use to kill tanks. I'm saying that it has the same exact effect: peel their defenses back. The magnitude is the same as well. Trying to calculate damage versus a tank will always be drastically overpowered when you compare them to the squishy, because... Well. You're comparing a tank to a squishy. 

Now, my example was 11.5 hits instead of 13, vs 38.5 hits vs 40. It is true that the fewer hits is more impactful, but you're ignoring the context. Let's use this example, without armor values-
10 dmg vs 100 hp =  10 hits. -squishy target
10 dmg vs 300 hp = 30 hits. -tanky target
30 dmg vs 300 hp = 10 hits (+ 20 dmg, +200 hp)
30 dmg vs 500 hp = 16.66 hits. (+20 dmg, +200 hp)
From this, we can extrapolate that buying health is WAY more valuable on squishies than tanks, right? That's why buying health on the squishy made him not be any squishier as the game passed, while the tank lost a dramatic amount of hits-to-kill from the same item. This also means that buying damage is purely a tank-busting concept, as squishies can too-easily make it so your damage is useless, right? OF COURSE NOT! I'm taking everything WAY out of context on purpose in this example. 

15 pen seems to have less of an effect vs tanks because, well shit, the tank actually has more than 15 mr. It's almost as if, the more tank items someone bought, the more damaging items you need to take them out. A squishy needs less damage to kill them because they bought no tank items, so a small amount of flat pen is enough. It's exactly the same effect, you just need more of it. I'M NOT SAYING FLAT PEN KILLS TANKS, because it's not something you can stack a lot of, but it does EXACTLY the same thing.

In practice, because percent pen exists, stacking the two IS better than just getting percent, especially versus tanks. This is not a reason to buy a Liandries as a tankbuster item, but it IS good to combine it with void staff if your character can make good use of it.

> Target w/ 15 mr: 13% etc etc

If you know your maths, you know displaying the percents in this way is incredibly misleading. 15 flat pen does exactly the same thing no matter how much magic resist they have, and by displaying it as "% increase" or "% decrease in their damage reduction", you are being disgraceful to statistics. 

x (100%) health + 300 mr = 400% effective health.
     -15 pen = 385% effective health.
x (100%) health + 15 mr = 115% effective health.
     -15 pen = 100% effective health.
It's -15% effective health no matter what.

Yes, it's still better to buy flat pen vs squishy targets (assuming flat pen options are good), but that's because 35% of 30 magic resist is 10, so buying a void staff is just a bad idea compared to just buying flat pen.

> [{quoted}](name=Backup4now,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=EKrfbpKo,comment-id=0009,timestamp=2017-02-04T05:16:21.035+0000)
>
> If you know your maths, you know displaying the percents in this way is incredibly misleading. 15 flat pen does exactly the same thing no matter how much magic resist they have, and by displaying it as "% increase" or "% decrease in their damage reduction", you are being disgraceful to statistics. 

Luckily I do know my maths, and it seems you are confused on the topic. Imagine you have a spell that does 100 nominal damage (before resistances). If you cast this spell on a champion who has 30 mr, you will deal 77 damage. 23 damage was absorbed. Now you purchase 15 magic pen, and cast the same 100 damage spell on the same 30 mr target (15 effective mr now). You now deal 87 damage. 13 damage was absorbed. You gained 10 damage from the 15 magic pen.

Now consider the same 100 damage spell on a 200 mr target. With 0 magic pen, you deal 33.3 damage. 66.6 damage was absorbed. Now add your 15 magic pen (185 effective mr), and you will deal 35.1 damage. You gained 1.8 damage from the 15 magic pen versus the tanky target, compared to gaining 10 damage versus the squishy target.

I hope my maths appear less misleading now. In fact, you don't have to take my word for it. Work out the numbers for yourself.

I think the ideal niche for Liandry's should be akin to black cleaver, but for CC heavy tanks.

I know that that's the direction they were originally hoping to push Abyssal towards, but if they made the item lower in AP (probably reverted back to 60, maybe brought lower), higher in HP (more appealing to tanks), and made the DoT also apply a weak stacking MR shred with a cap (i.e. shreds 2% MR per second for x seconds, doubled vs movement impaired units, up to y% shred).

It should not be a strong damage item in the least, but it should have a lot of utility to make your APC hit like a truck. Tying the shred to a DoT effect will also ensure that you *don't* get situations where Tank engages with full rotation—>enemies' MR is instantly shredded—>APC one-shots enemy team.

With this type of design, it'll probably still be a decent pick for DoT mages, but it shouldn't be core on them.
